title: Coming Soon to Your Podcast Feed: Science, Quickly
intro: A new era in Scientific American audio history is about to drop starting next week. Get ready for a science variety show guaranteed to quench your curiosity in under 10 minutes.

transcript.author: SUBSCRIBE
transcript.text: :Apple | Spotify [Music]

transcript.author: DelViscio:
transcript.text: This is Jeff DelViscio, chief multimedia editor here at Scientific American.

transcript.author: Bose:
transcript.text: And this is Tulika Bose, senior multimedia editor.

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : Hey Tulika. Do you remember the year 2006?

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: : Sure, Jeff. A lot happened.

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : The existence of Dark matter was confirmed. The missing link between fish and stuff with four legs–a fossil of a creature dubbed Tiktaalik–was found. Twitter launched. But Pluto also lost its planetary status.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: : Aww, poor dwarf planet Pluto. And we lost “Crocodile Hunter” Steve Irwin.

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : A moment of silence.

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : And everyone believed that drinking wine would help you live longer. Do you remember ... res, res ...

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: : Oh yeah, resvere ... resvere ...

transcript.author: DelViscio and Bose
transcript.text: : Resveratrol.

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : Right ....

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: : Yeah ... and everyone also believed that our newly-launched podcast, 60-Second Science, would stay 60 seconds.

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : [Laughs]

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: : [Laughs] But over those 15+ years and thousands of episodes of our beloved science podcast later …

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : ... it became very clear that 60-Second Science …

transcript.author: Bose:
transcript.text: …wasn’t actually going to stay 60 seconds. And of those 3,000 episodes, how many were actually 60 seconds?

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : You know I'm not sure, but I think we started to slide in the mid-2010’s.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: : Yeah, that’s the number one piece of feedback I get from everyone who listens to the show and loves it. Your show isn’t 60 seconds! It’s a lie! Including someone who's going to write for us who listened to it on their school bus.

transcript.author: DelViscio:
transcript.text: Well, in their honor, we’re not going to live the lie anymore.

transcript.author: Bose:
transcript.text: No more, no more. So, because of that we’re going to be correcting the serial error in a big way.

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : It's a new era in Scientific American podcast history.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: : Einstein might have written for us back in the 1950’s ...

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : ... but you don’t have to be an Einstein to listen to this podcast. It’s a science pod for everyone.

transcript.author: Bose:
transcript.text: We’ll be expanding our hosts, our coverage, and most importantly, the space time continuum of this podcast.

transcript.author: DelViscio:
transcript.text: Here’s a little taste of the stories–from their new hosts—we have coming ....

transcript.author: Hamilton Morris
transcript.text: : Hi, I'm Hamilton Morris, and I'll be talking about chemistry, pharmacology and new research on psycho-active drugs for Scientific American's Science, Quickly.

transcript.author: Shayla Love:'
transcript.text: Hey, this is Shayla Love and I'm going to take you inside the brain, in love. [Music]

transcript.author: Christopher Intagliata:'
transcript.text: This is Christopher Intagliata and I'm searching for the pools of life. [Music]

transcript.author: Allison Parshall:
transcript.text: I'm Allison Parshall and I'm going to be taking you to a world where AI makes music. [Music]

transcript.author: Jacob Job:
transcript.text: This is Jacob Job and together we'll explore bird conservation via nocturnal migration. [Music]

transcript.author: Kelso Harper:'
transcript.text: This is Kelso Harper and I'll be exploring the queerness of nature. [Music]

transcript.author: Jason Drakeford:'
transcript.text: This is Jason Drakeford and together we'll track down the sounds of outer space. [Music]

transcript.author: Meghan McDonough:
transcript.text: This is Meghan McDonough and I'll be exploring the science of pleasure. [Music]

transcript.author: Shannon Liao:'
transcript.text: My name is Shannon Liao and I'll be covering the science of video games and everything you might want to know about that. [Music]

transcript.author: Tanya Lewis
transcript.text: : This is Tanya Lewis.

transcript.author: Josh Fischman
transcript.text: : And Josh Fischman, and we'll be back with Your Health, Quickly.

transcript.author: Lewis:'
transcript.text: Health news you can use on COVID ...

transcript.author: Fischman:'
transcript.text: ... but now also on stuff beyond the pandemic.

transcript.author: Lewis:'
transcript.text: Medicine.

transcript.author: Fischman:'
transcript.text: Neuroscience.

transcript.author: Lewis:'
transcript.text: Nutrition.

transcript.author: Fischman:'
transcript.text: Exercise.

transcript.author: Lewis:'
transcript.text: And a whole lot more. [Music]

transcript.author: Bose:
transcript.text: This sounds fascinating.

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : And not one of these podcasts is 60 seconds.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: : Oh thank God. But we’re still going to respect your time. Fascinating and fast.

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : You might even say, “Science, Quickly .... ”

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: : You know what? That’s great. Let’s go with that.

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: : So join us ...

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: : ... for Science, Quickly.

transcript.author: DelViscio:
transcript.text: Coming to this podcast feed ...

transcript.author: Bose:
transcript.text: ... this brand new, refreshed podcast feed ...

transcript.author: DelViscio:
transcript.text: ... yes, indeed, Monday February 13.

transcript.author: Bose:
transcript.text: I preferred Tuesday.

transcript.author: DelViscio:
transcript.text: Heartbreaking, I know.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: : But Monday it is. I’m not superstitious, I swear.

transcript.author: DelViscio:
transcript.text: See you all then. [Music] The Science, Quickly music was composed by Dominic Smith. [The above is a transcript of this podcast.]
